The **Leaning Tower of Pisa** ([Italian](/wiki/Italian_language "Italian
language"): _Torre pendente di Pisa_) or simply the **Tower of Pisa** (_Torre
di Pisa_ [[ˈtorre di ˈpiːza]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Italian "Help:IPA/Italian")) is
the _[campanile](/wiki/Campanile "Campanile")_ , or freestanding [bell
tower](/wiki/Bell_tower "Bell tower"), of the [cathedral](/wiki/Cathedral
"Cathedral") of the [Italian city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Italy "List of
cities in Italy") of [Pisa](/wiki/Pisa "Pisa"), known worldwide for its
unintended tilt. The tower is situated behind the [Pisa
Cathedral](/wiki/Pisa_Cathedral "Pisa Cathedral") and is the third oldest
structure in the city's Cathedral Square (_[Piazza del
Duomo](/wiki/Piazza_del_Duomo,_Pisa "Piazza del Duomo, Pisa")_), after the
cathedral and the [Pisa Baptistry](/wiki/Pisa_Baptistry "Pisa Baptistry").

The tower's tilt began during construction in the 12th century, caused by an
inadequate [foundation](/wiki/Foundation_\(engineering\) "Foundation
\(engineering\)") on ground too soft on one side to properly support the
structure's weight. The tilt increased in the decades before the structure was
completed in the 14th century. It gradually increased until the structure was
stabilized (and the tilt partially corrected) by efforts in the late 20th and
early 21st centuries.

The height of the tower is 55.86 metres (183.27 feet) from the ground on the
low side and 56.67 metres (185.93 feet) on the high side. The width of the
walls at the base is 2.44 m (8 ft 0.06 in). Its weight is estimated at 14,500
[metric tons](/wiki/Tonne "Tonne") (16,000 [short tons](/wiki/Short_ton "Short
ton")).[1] The tower has 296 or 294 steps; the seventh floor has two fewer
steps on the north-facing staircase. Prior to restoration work performed
between 1990 and 2001, the tower leaned at an angle of 5.5 degrees,[2][3][4]
but the tower now leans at about 3.99 degrees.[5]

## Architect

There has been controversy about the real identity of the architect of the
Leaning Tower of Pisa. For many years, the design was attributed to Guglielmo
and [Bonanno Pisano](/wiki/Bonanno_Pisano "Bonanno Pisano"),[6] a well-known
12th-century resident artist of Pisa, famous for his [bronze](/wiki/Bronze
"Bronze") casting, particularly in the [Pisa Duomo](/wiki/Piazza_dei_Miracoli
"Piazza dei Miracoli"). Pisano left Pisa in 1185 for [Monreale](/wiki/Monreale
"Monreale"), Sicily, only to come back and die in his home town. A piece of
cast bearing his name was discovered at the foot of the tower in 1820, but
this may be related to the bronze door in the façade of the cathedral that was
destroyed in 1595. A 2001 study[7] seems to indicate
[Diotisalvi](/wiki/Diotisalvi "Diotisalvi") was the original architect, due to
the time of construction and affinity with other Diotisalvi works, notably the
bell tower of [San Nicola](/wiki/San_Nicola,_Pisa "San Nicola, Pisa") and the
[Baptistery](/wiki/Baptistery "Baptistery"), both in Pisa.

Leaning Tower of Pisa

Construction of the tower occurred in three stages over 199 years. Work on the
ground floor of the white marble campanile began on August 14, 1173 during a
period of military success and prosperity. This ground floor is a [blind
arcade](/wiki/Blind_arcade "Blind arcade") articulated by engaged columns with
classical Corinthian [capitals](/wiki/Capital_\(architecture\) "Capital
\(architecture\)").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The tower began to sink after construction had progressed to the second floor
in 1178. This was due to a mere three-metre foundation, set in weak, unstable
[subsoil](/wiki/Subsoil "Subsoil"), a design that was flawed from the
beginning. Construction was subsequently halted for almost a century, because
the [Republic of Pisa](/wiki/Republic_of_Pisa "Republic of Pisa") was almost
continually engaged in battles with [Genoa](/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa "Republic
of Genoa"), [Lucca](/wiki/Republic_of_Lucca "Republic of Lucca"), and
[Florence](/wiki/Florence "Florence"). This allowed time for the underlying
soil to settle. Otherwise, the tower would almost certainly have
toppled.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In 1198, clocks were temporarily installed on
the third floor of the unfinished construction.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In 1272, construction resumed under [Giovanni di
Simone](/w/index.php?title=Giovanni_di_Simone&action=edit&redlink=1 "Giovanni
di Simone \(page does not exist\)"), architect of the
[Camposanto](/wiki/Piazza_dei_Miracoli#Camposanto "Piazza dei Miracoli"). In
an effort to compensate for the tilt, the engineers built upper floors with
one side taller than the other. Because of this, the tower is curved.[8]
Construction was halted again in 1284 when the Pisans were defeated by the
Genoans in the [Battle of Meloria](/wiki/Battle_of_Meloria_\(1284\) "Battle of
Meloria \(1284\)").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The seventh floor was completed in 1319. The bell-chamber was finally added in
1372. It was built by [Tommaso di Andrea
Pisano](/w/index.php?title=Tommaso_di_Andrea_Pisano&action=edit&redlink=1
"Tommaso di Andrea Pisano \(page does not exist\)"), who succeeded in
harmonizing the [Gothic](/wiki/Gothic_architecture "Gothic architecture")
elements of the bell-chamber with the
[Romanesque](/wiki/Romanesque_architecture "Romanesque architecture") style of
the tower.[9] There are seven bells, one for each note of the musical major
scale. The largest one was installed in 1655.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

After a phase (1990–2001) of structural strengthening,[10] the tower is
currently undergoing gradual surface restoration, in order to repair visible
damage, mostly corrosion and blackening. These are particularly pronounced due
to the tower's age and its exposure to wind and rain.[11]

### Timeline

  * On January 5, 1172, Donna Berta di Bernardo, a widow and resident of the house of dell'Opera di Santa Maria, bequeathed sixty [soldi](/wiki/Solidus_\(coin\) "Solidus \(coin\)") to the _Opera Campanilis petrarum Sancte Marie_. The sum was then used toward the purchase of a few stones which still form the base of the bell tower.[12]
  * On August 9, 1173, the foundations of the tower were laid.
  * Nearly four centuries later [Giorgio Vasari](/wiki/Giorgio_Vasari "Giorgio Vasari") wrote: "Guglielmo, according to what is being said, in [this] year 1174 with Bonanno as sculptor, laid the foundations of the bell tower of the cathedral in Pisa."
  * On December 27, 1233, the worker Benenato, son of Gerardo Bottici, oversaw the continuation of the construction of the bell tower.[13]
  * On February 23, 1260, Guido Speziale, son of Giovanni, a worker on the cathedral Santa Maria Maggiore, was elected to oversee the building of the tower.[14]
  * On April 12, 1264, the master builder Giovanni di Simone and 23 workers went to the mountains close to Pisa to cut marble. The cut stones were given to Rainaldo Speziale, worker of St. Francesco.[15]
  * Giorgio Vasari indicated that Tommaso di Andrea Pisano was the designer of the belfry[16] between 1360 and 1370.

### Builders

  * One possible known builder of Pisa Tower was [Gerardo di Gerardo](/w/index.php?title=Gerardo_di_Gerardo&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gerardo di Gerardo \(page does not exist\)"). His name appears as a witness to the above legacy of Berta di Bernardo as "Master Gerardo", and as a worker whose name was Gerardo.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * A more probable builder was Diotisalvi, because of the construction period and the structure's affinities with other buildings in Pisa, but he usually signed his works, and there is no signature by him in the bell tower.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * Giovanni di Simone was known to be heavily involved in the completion of the tower, under the direction of [Giovanni Pisano](/wiki/Giovanni_Pisano "Giovanni Pisano"), who at the time was master builder of the [Opera di Santa Maria Maggiore](/w/index.php?title=Opera_di_Santa_Maria_Maggiore&action=edit&redlink=1 "Opera di Santa Maria Maggiore \(page does not exist\)"). Di Simone could be the same Giovanni Pisano who completed the belfry tower.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## History following construction

[Galileo Galilei](/wiki/Galileo_Galilei "Galileo Galilei") is said to have
[dropped two cannonballs](/wiki/Galileo%27s_Leaning_Tower_of_Pisa_experiment
"Galileo's Leaning Tower of Pisa experiment") of different [masses](/wiki/Mass
"Mass") from the tower to demonstrate that their [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed")
of descent was independent of their mass. However, the only primary source for
this is the biography _Racconto istorico della vita di Galileo Galilei
(Historical Account of the Life of Galileo Galilei)_ , written by Galileo's
secretary [Vincenzo Viviani](/wiki/Vincenzo_Viviani "Vincenzo Viviani") and
published in 1717, long after Viviani's death.[17][18]

During [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), the
[Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") suspected that
the Germans were using the tower as an observation post. A [U.S.
Army](/wiki/U.S._Army "U.S. Army") [sergeant](/wiki/Sergeant "Sergeant") sent
to confirm the presence of German troops in the tower was impressed by the
beauty of the cathedral and its campanile, and thus refrained from ordering an
[artillery](/wiki/Artillery "Artillery") strike, sparing it from
destruction.[19][20]

Numerous efforts have been made to restore the tower to a vertical orientation
or at least keep it from falling over. Most of these efforts failed; some
worsened the tilt. On February 27, 1964, the government of Italy requested aid
in preventing the tower from toppling. It was, however, considered important
to retain the current tilt, due to the role that this element played in
promoting the tourism industry of Pisa.[21]

A multinational [task force](/wiki/Task_force "Task force") of engineers,
mathematicians, and historians gathered on the [Azores](/wiki/Azores "Azores")
islands to discuss stabilisation methods. It was found that the tilt was
increasing in combination with the softer foundations on the lower side. Many
methods were proposed to stabilise the tower, including the addition of 800
tonnes of lead counterweights to the raised end of the base.[22]

The tower and the neighbouring [cathedral](/wiki/Cathedral "Cathedral"),
[baptistery](/wiki/Baptistery "Baptistery"), and cemetery are included in the
[Piazza del Duomo](/wiki/Piazza_del_Duomo,_Pisa "Piazza del Duomo, Pisa")
[UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site"),
which was declared in 1987.[23]

The tower was closed to the public on January 7, 1990, after more than two
decades of stabilisation studies and spurred by the abrupt collapse of the
[Civic Tower of Pavia](/wiki/Civic_Tower_\(Pavia\) "Civic Tower \(Pavia\)") in
1989. The bells were removed to relieve some weight, and cables were cinched
around the third level and anchored several hundred meters away. Apartments
and houses in the path of the tower were vacated for safety. The solution
chosen to prevent the collapse of the tower was to slightly straighten it to a
safer angle by removing 38 cubic metres (1,342 cubic feet) of soil from
underneath the raised end. The tower was straightened by 45 centimetres (17.7
inches), returning to its 1838 position. After a decade of corrective
reconstruction and stabilization efforts, the tower was reopened to the public
on December 15, 2001 and was declared stable for at least another 300
years.[22] In total, 70 metric tons (77 short tons) of earth were removed.[24]

In May 2008, engineers announced that the tower had been stabilized such that
it had stopped moving for the first time in its history. They stated that it
would be stable for at least 200 years.[24]

## Guinness World Records

Two German churches have challenged the tower's status as the world's most
lop-sided building: the 15th-century square [Leaning Tower of
Suurhusen](/wiki/Leaning_Tower_of_Suurhusen "Leaning Tower of Suurhusen") and
the 14th-century bell tower in the town of [Bad
Frankenhausen](/wiki/Bad_Frankenhausen#Sights "Bad Frankenhausen").[25]
_[Guinness World Records](/wiki/Guinness_World_Records "Guinness World
Records")_ measured the Pisa and Suurhusen towers, finding the former's tilt
to be 3.97 degrees.[26] In June 2010, _Guinness World Records_ certified the
[Capital Gate](/wiki/Capital_Gate "Capital Gate") building in [Abu
Dhabi](/wiki/Abu_Dhabi "Abu Dhabi"), [UAE](/wiki/UAE "UAE") as the "World's
Furthest Leaning Man-made Tower".[27] The Capital Gate tower has an 18-degree
slope, almost five times more than the Pisa Tower; however the Capital Gate
tower has been deliberately engineered to slant. The [Leaning Tower of
Wanaka](/wiki/Puzzling_World,_New_Zealand#The_Leaning_Tower_of_Wanaka
"Puzzling World, New Zealand") in [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New
Zealand"), also deliberately built, leans at 53 degrees to the ground.[28]

## Technical information

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Leaning_tower_of_pisa_cyark.JPG/300px-
Leaning_tower_of_pisa_cyark.JPG)](/wiki/File:Leaning_tower_of_pisa_cyark.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Leaning_tower_of_pisa_cyark.JPG "Enlarge")

An elevation image of the Leaning Tower of Pisa cut with [laser
scan](/wiki/3D_Scanner "3D Scanner") data from a [University of
Ferrara](/wiki/University_of_Ferrara "University of
Ferrara")/[CyArk](/wiki/CyArk "CyArk") research partnership, with source image
accurate down to 5 mm (0.2 in)

  * Elevation of Piazza del Duomo: about 2 metres (6 feet, DMS)
  * Height from the ground floor: 55.863 metres (183 ft 3 in), 8 stories
  * Height from the foundation floor: 58.36 m (191 ft 5.64 in)
  * Outer diameter of base: 15.484 metres (50 ft 9.6 in)
  * Inner diameter of base: 7.368 metres (24 ft 2.1 in)
  * Angle of slant: 3.97 degrees[26] or 3.9 metres (12 ft 10 in) from the vertical[29]
  * Weight: 14,700 metric tons (16,200 short tons)
  * Thickness of walls at the base: 2.44 metres (8 ft 0 in)
  * Total number of bells: 7, tuned to [musical scale](/wiki/Musical_scale "Musical scale"), clockwise 
    * 1st bell: L'Assunta, cast in 1654 by [Giovanni Pietro Orlandi](/w/index.php?title=Giovanni_Pietro_Orlandi&action=edit&redlink=1 "Giovanni Pietro Orlandi \(page does not exist\)"), weight 3,620 kg (7,981 lb)
    * 2nd bell: Il Crocifisso, cast in 1572 by [Vincenzo Possenti](/w/index.php?title=Vincenzo_Possenti&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vincenzo Possenti \(page does not exist\)"), weight 2,462 kg (5,428 lb)
    * 3rd bell: San Ranieri, cast in 1719–1721 by [Giovanni Andrea Moreni](/w/index.php?title=Giovanni_Andrea_Moreni&action=edit&redlink=1 "Giovanni Andrea Moreni \(page does not exist\)"), weight 1,448 kg (3,192 lb)
    * 4th bell: La Terza (1st small one), cast in 1473, weight 300 kg (661 lb)
    * 5th bell: La Pasquereccia or La Giustizia, cast in 1262 by [Lotteringo](/w/index.php?title=Lotteringo&action=edit&redlink=1 "Lotteringo \(page does not exist\)"), weight 1,014 kg (2,235 lb)
    * 6th bell: Il Vespruccio (2nd small one), cast in the 14th century and again in 1501 by [Nicola di Jacopo](/w/index.php?title=Nicola_di_Jacopo&action=edit&redlink=1 "Nicola di Jacopo \(page does not exist\)"), weight 1,000 kg (2,205 lb)
    * 7th bell: [Dal Pozzo](/wiki/Carlo_Antonio_Dal_Pozzo "Carlo Antonio Dal Pozzo"), cast in 1606 and again in 2004, weight 652 kg (1,437 lb)[30]
  * Number of steps to the top: 296[31]

About the 5th bell: The name _Pasquareccia_ comes from _Easter_ , because it
used to ring on Easter day. However, this bell is older than the bell-chamber
itself, and comes from the tower Vergata in _Palazzo Pretorio_ in Pisa, where
it was called _La Giustizia_ (The Justice). The bell was tolled to announce
executions of criminals and traitors, including [Count
Ugolino](/wiki/Ugolino_della_Gherardesca "Ugolino della Gherardesca") in
1289.[32] A new bell was installed in the bell tower at the end of the 18th
century to replace the broken _Pasquareccia_.

The circular shape and great height (currently 55.86 m (183 ft 3.21 in) on the
lowest side and 56.67 m (185 ft 11.10 in) m on the highest) of the campanile
were unusual for their time, and the crowning belfry is stylistically distinct
from the rest of the construction. This belfry incorporates a 14 cm (5.5 in)
correction for the inclined axis below. The siting of the campanile within the
Piazza del Duomo diverges from the axial alignment of the cathedral and
baptistery of the Piazza del Duomo.
